header.name: boost/test/data/config.hpp
header.para: common dataset macros

macro.purpose: Defined when the random dataset feature is not available.

macro.name: BOOST_TEST_NO_GRID_COMPOSITION_AVAILABLE
macro.purpose: Defined when grid composition of datasets is not available.

header.name: boost/test/data/for_each_sample.hpp
header.para: Defines for_each_sample algorithm.

header.name: boost/test/data/monomorphic/array.hpp
header.para: Defines monomorphic dataset based on C type arrays.

class.purpose: Dataset view of a C array.

struct-specialization.name: is_dataset
struct-specialization.purpose: An array dataset is a dataset.

header.name: boost/test/data/monomorphic/collection.hpp
header.para: Defines monomorphic dataset based on forward iterable sequence.

class.name: collection
class.purpose: Dataset from a forward iterable container (collection)

description.para: This dataset is applicable to any container implementing a forward iterator. Note that container with one element will be considered as singletons. This dataset is constructible with the boost::unit_test::data::make function.

method.name: col
method.purpose: Returns the underlying collection.

method.name: size
method.purpose: dataset interface

constructor.purpose: Constructor consumed a temporary collection or stores a reference.

struct-specialization.name: is_dataset
struct-specialization.purpose: A collection from a forward iterable container is a dataset.

header.name: boost/test/data/monomorphic/fwd.hpp
header.para: Forward declares monomorphic datasets interfaces.

struct.name: is_dataset
struct.purpose: Helper metafunction indicating if the specified type is a dataset.

struct-specialization.name: is_dataset
struct-specialization.purpose: A reference to a dataset is a dataset.

struct-specialization.name: is_dataset
struct-specialization.purpose: A const dataset is a dataset.

overloaded-function.name: make

signature.type: std::enable_if<!is_forward_iterable< T >::value &&!monomorphic::is_dataset< T >::value &&!is_array< typename remove_reference< T >::type >::value, monomorphic::singleton< T > >::type

overloaded-function.purpose: Creates a dataset from a value, a collection or an array.

header.name: boost/test/data/monomorphic/generate.hpp
header.para: Defines generic interface for monomorphic dataset based on generator.

class.name: generated_by
class.purpose: Generators interface.

description.para:
This class implements the dataset concept over a generator. Examples of generators are:
xrange_t
random_t

The generator concept is the following:
the type of the generated samples is given by field sample
the member function capacity should return the size of the collection being generated (potentially infinite)
the member function next should change the state of the generator to the next generated value
the member function reset should put the state of the object in the same state as right after its instanciation

method.name: size
method.purpose: Size of the underlying dataset.

method.name: begin
method.purpose: Iterator on the beginning of the dataset.

struct-specialization.name: is_dataset
struct-specialization.purpose: A generated dataset is a dataset.

header.name: boost/test/data/monomorphic/generators.hpp
header.para: Defines specific generators.

header.name: boost/test/data/monomorphic/generators/keywords.hpp
header.para: Keywords used in generator interfaces.

header.name: boost/test/data/monomorphic/generators/random.hpp
header.para: Random generator.

class.name: random_t
class.purpose: Generator for the random sequences.

description.para: This class implements the generator concept (see boost::unit_test::data::monomorphic::generated_by) for implementing a random number generator.

method.name: seed
method.purpose: Sets the seed of the pseudo-random number engine.

overloaded-function.name: random
overloaded-function.purpose: Returns an infinite sequence of random numbers.

listitem.para: The first overload uses the default distribution, which is uniform and which elements are double type (the values are in [0, 1) ).

The second overload generates numbers in the given interval. The distribution is uniform (in [begin, end) for real numbers, and in [begin, end] for integers). The type of the distribution is deduced from the type of the begin and end parameters.

The third overload generates numbers using the named parameter inside params , which are:
distribution: the distribution used. In this overload, since the type of the samples cannot be deduced, the samples are of type double and the distribution is uniform real in [0, 1).
seed: the seed for generating the values
engine: the random number generator engine

description.para:
The function returns an object that implements the dataset API.
This function is available only for C++11 capable compilers.

header.name: boost/test/data/monomorphic/generators/xrange.hpp
header.para: Defines range generator.

class.name: xrange_t
class.purpose: Generator for the range sequences.

description.para: This class implements the generator concept (see boost::unit_test::data::monomorphic::generated_by) for implementing a range like sequence of numbers.

signature.type: enable_if_c< nfp::is_named_param_pack< Params >::value, monomorphic::generated_by< monomorphic::xrange_t< SampleType > > >::type

listitem.para: begin_val indicates the start of the sequence (default to 0).
end_val is the end of the sequence. If ommited, the dataset has infinite size.
step_val is the step between two consecutive elements of the sequence, and defaults to 1.

param is the named parameters that describe the sequence. The following parameters are accepted:
begin: same meaning begin_val
end: same meaning as end_val
step: same meaning as step_val

description.para: The returned value is an object that implements the dataset API.

note.para: the step size cannot be null, and it should be positive if begin_val < end_val, negative otherwise.

header.name: boost/test/data/monomorphic/grid.hpp
header.para: Defines monomorphic dataset n+m dimentional *. Samples in this dataset is grid of elements in DataSet1 and DataSet2. There will be total |DataSet1| * |DataSet2| samples.

class.name: grid
class.purpose: Implements the dataset resulting from a cartesian product/grid operation on datasets.

description.para: The arity of the resulting dataset is the sum of the arity of its operands.

struct.name: grid
struct.purpose: Result type of the grid operation on dataset.

header.name: boost/test/data/monomorphic/initializer_list.hpp
header.para: Defines monomorphic dataset based on C++11 initializer_list template.

class.name: init_list
class.purpose: Dataset view of a C array.

method.name: size
method.purpose: dataset interface

struct-specialization.name: is_dataset
struct-specialization.purpose: An array dataset is a dataset.

header.name: boost/test/data/monomorphic/join.hpp
header.para: Defines dataset join operation.

class.name: join
class.purpose: Defines a new dataset from the concatenation of two datasets.

description.para: The size of the resulting dataset is the sum of the two underlying datasets. The arity of the datasets should match.

method.name: size
method.purpose: dataset interface

struct.name: join
struct.purpose: Result type of the join operation on datasets.

function.name: operator+
function.type: boost::lazy_enable_if_c< is_dataset< DataSet1 >::value &&is_dataset< DataSet2 >::value, result_of::join< mpl::identity< DataSet1 >, mpl::identity< DataSet2 > >>::type

class.purpose: Models a single element data set.

method.purpose: Value access method.

method.purpose: dataset interface

header.name: boost/test/data/monomorphic/zip.hpp
header.para: Defines monomorphic dataset based on zipping of 2 other monomorphic datasets.

class.name: zip
class.purpose: Zip datasets.

description.para: A zip of two datasets is a dataset whose arity is the sum of the operand datasets arity. The size is given by the function creating the instance (see operator^ on datasets).
The datasets are moved and not copied.

struct-specialization.name: is_dataset
struct-specialization.purpose: Zipped datasets results in a dataset.

struct.name: zip
struct.purpose: Result type of the zip operator.

header.name: boost/test/data/size.hpp
header.para: simple dataset size abstraction (can be infinite)

class.name: size_t
class.purpose: Utility for handling the size of a datasets.

header.name: boost/test/data/test_case.hpp
header.para: test case family based on data generator

header.name: boost/test/debug.hpp
header.para: defines portable debug interfaces
Intended to standardize interface of programs with debuggers

struct.name: dbg_startup_info
struct.purpose: Collection of data, which is used by debugger starter routine.

data-member.name: pid
data-member.purpose: pid of a program to attach to

data-member.name: break_or_continue
data-member.purpose: what to do after debugger is attached

data-member.name: binary_path
data-member.purpose: path to executable for current process

data-member.name: display
data-member.purpose: if debugger has a GUI, which display to use (on UNIX)

data-member.name: init_done_lock
data-member.purpose: path to a uniquely named lock file, which is used to pause current application while debugger is being initialized

typedef.name: dbg_starter
typedef.purpose: Signature of debugger starter routine. Takes an instance of dbg_startup_into as only argument.

function.name: under_debugger
function.purpose: Checks if programs runs under debugger.

returns.para: true if current process is under debugger. False otherwise

function.name: debugger_break
function.purpose: Cause program to break execution in debugger at call point.

function.name: set_debugger

description.para: Unique id for debugger configuration (for example, gdb)
Optional starter routine for selected configuration (use only you want to define your own configuration)

function.purpose: Specifies which debugger to use when attaching and optionally what routine to use to start that debugger.

description.para:
There are many different debuggers available for different platforms. Some of them also can be used in a different setups/configuratins. For example, gdb can be used in plain text mode, inside ddd, inside (x)emacs or in a separate xterm window. Boost.Test identifies each configuration with unique string. Also different debuggers configurations require different routines which is specifically tailored to start that debugger configuration. Boost.Test comes with set of predefined configuration names and corresponding routines for these configurations:
TODO

You can use this routine to select which one of the predefined debugger configurations to use in which case you do not need to provide starter routine (the one provided by Boost.Test will be used). You can also use this routine to select your own debugger by providing unique configuration id and starter routine for this configuration.

returns.para: Id of previously selected debugger configuration

function.name: attach_debugger

description.para: tells what we wan to do after the debugger is attached. If true - process execution breaks in the point in invocation of this function. Otherwise execution continues, but now it is under the debugger

function.purpose: Attaches debugger to the current process.

description.para: Using currently selected debugger, this routine attempts to attach the debugger to this process.

returns.para: true if debugger successfully attached. False otherwise

function.name: detect_memory_leaks

description.para: boolean switch
file, where the report should be directed to

function.purpose: Switches on/off memory leaks detection.

description.para: On platforms where memory leak detection is possible inside of running application (at the moment this is only Windows family) you can switch this feature on and off using this interface. In addition you can specify the name of the file to write a report into. Otherwise the report is going to be generated in standard error stream.

function.name: break_memory_alloc

description.para: Specific memory allocation number

function.purpose: Causes program to break execution in debugger at specific allocation point.

description.para: On some platforms/memory managers (at the moment only on Windows/Visual Studio) one can tell a C Runtime to break on specific memory allocation. This can be used in combination with memory leak detection (which reports leaked memory allocation number) to locate the place where leak initiated.

header.name: boost/test/debug_config.hpp
header.para: user's config for Boost.Test debugging support
This file is intended to be edited by end user to specify varios macros, which configure debugger interface Alterntively you can set these parameters in your own sources/makefiles

header.name: boost/test/execution_monitor.hpp
header.para: Defines public interface of the Execution Monitor and related classes.

class.name: execution_exception
class.purpose: This class is used to report any kind of an failure during execution of a monitored function inside of execution_monitor.

description.para: The instance of this class is thrown out of execution_monitor::execute invocation when failure is detected. Regardless of a kind of failure occurred the instance will provide a uniform way to catch and report it.

One important design rationale for this class is that we should be ready to work after fatal memory corruptions or out of memory conditions. To facilitate this class never allocates any memory and assumes that strings it refers to are either some constants or live in a some kind of persistent (preallocated) memory.

struct.name: location
struct.purpose: Simple model for the location of failure in a source code.

data-member.name: m_file_name
data-member.purpose: File name.

data-member.name: m_line_num
data-member.purpose: Line number.

data-member.name: m_function
data-member.purpose: Function name.

description.para: error code
error message
error location

constructor.purpose: Constructs instance based on message, location and error code.

enum.name: error_code
enum.purpose: These values are sometimes used as program return codes. The particular values have been chosen to avoid conflicts with commonly used program return codes: values < 100 are often user assigned, values > 255 are sometimes used to report system errors. Gaps in values allow for orderly expansion.

description.para: (1) Only uncaught C++ exceptions are treated as errors. If a function catches a C++ exception, it never reaches the execution_monitor. The implementation decides what is a system_fatal_error and what is just a system_exception. Fatal errors are so likely to have corrupted machine state (like a stack overflow or addressing exception) that it is unreasonable to continue execution.

note.para: (2) These errors include Unix signals and Windows structured exceptions. They are often initiated by hardware traps.

class.name: execution_monitor
class.purpose: Function execution monitor.

description.para: This class is used to uniformly detect and report an occurrence of several types of signals and exceptions, reducing various errors to a uniform execution_exception that is returned to a caller.

The executiom_monitor behavior can be customized through a set of public parameters (properties) associated with the execution_monitor instance. All parameters are implemented as public unit_test::readwrite_property data members of the class execution_monitor.

data-member.name: p_catch_system_errors
data-member.purpose: Should monitor catch system errors.

description.para: The p_catch_system_errors property is a boolean flag (default value is true) specifying whether or not execution_monitor should trap system errors/system level exceptions/signals, which would cause program to crash in a regular case (without execution_monitor). Set this property to false, for example, if you wish to force coredump file creation. The Unit Test Framework provides a runtime parameter \-\-catch_system_errors=yes to alter the behavior in monitored test cases.

data-member.name: p_auto_start_dbg
data-member.purpose: Should monitor try to attach debugger in case of caught system error.

description.para: The p_auto_start_dbg property is a boolean flag (default value is false) specifying whether or not execution_monitor should try to attach debugger in case system error is caught.

data-member.name: p_timeout
data-member.purpose: Specifies the seconds that elapse before a timer_error occurs.

description.para: The p_timeout property is an integer timeout (in seconds) for monitored function execution. Use this parameter to monitor code with possible deadlocks or indefinite loops. This feature is only available for some operating systems (not yet Microsoft Windows).

data-member.name: p_use_alt_stack
data-member.purpose: Should monitor use alternative stack for the signal catching.

description.para: The p_use_alt_stack property is a boolean flag (default value is false) specifying whether or not execution_monitor should use an alternative stack for the sigaction based signal catching. When enabled the signals are delivered to the execution_monitor on a stack different from current execution stack, which is safer in case if it is corrupted by monitored function. For more details on alternative stack handling see appropriate manuals.

data-member.name: p_detect_fp_exceptions
data-member.purpose: Should monitor try to detect hardware floating point exceptions (!= 0), and which specific exception to catch.

description.para: The p_detect_fp_exceptions property is a boolean flag (default value is false) specifying whether or not execution_monitor should install hardware traps for the floating point exception on platforms where it's supported.

method.name: execute

description.para: Function to monitor

method.purpose: Execution monitor entry point for functions returning integer value.

description.para: This method executes supplied function F inside a try/catch block and also may include other unspecified platform dependent error detection code.
This method throws an execution_exception on an uncaught C++ exception, a hardware or software signal, trap, or other user exception.

note.para: execute() doesn't consider it an error for F to return a non-zero value.

returns.para: value returned by function call F().

method.name: vexecute

description.para: Function to monitor

method.purpose: Execution monitor entry point for functions returning void.

description.para:
This method is semantically identical to execution_monitor::execute, but des't produce any result code.
See Also:
execute

method.name: register_exception_translator

purpose.para: type of the exception we register a translator for
type of the translator we register for this exception

description.para: translator function object with the signature void (ExceptionType const&)
tag associated with this translator

method.purpose: Registers custom (user supplied) exception translator.

method.name: erase_exception_translator

description.para: tag associated with translator you wants to erase

method.purpose: Erases custom exception translator based on a tag.

description.para: Use the same tag as the one used during translator registration

method.name: erase_exception_translator
method.purpose: Erases custom exception translator based on an exception type.

description.para: tparam ExceptionType Exception type for which you want to erase the translator

constructor.purpose: Default constructor initializes all execution monitor properties.

class.name: execution_aborted
class.purpose: This is a trivial default constructible class. Use it to report graceful abortion of a monitored function execution.

header.name: boost/test/framework.hpp
header.para: Defines Unit Test Framework mono-state interfaces. The framework interfaces are based on Monostate design pattern.

method.name: is_empty
method.purpose: Is there any context?

method.name: next
method.purpose: Give me next frame; empty - last frame.

struct.name: internal_error
struct.purpose: This exception type is used to report internal Boost.Test framework errors.

struct.name: setup_error
struct.purpose: This exception type is used to report test module setup errors.

function.name: init

description.para: test module initialization routine
command line arguments collection
command line arguments collection

function.purpose: This function performs initialization of the framework mono-state.

description.para: It needs to be called every time before the test is started.

function.name: finalize_setup_phase

description.para: Optional id of the test unit representing root of test tree. If absent, master test suite is used

function.purpose: This function applies all the decorators and figures out default run status. This argument facilitates an ability of the test cases to prepare some other test units (primarily used internally for self testing).

function.name: test_in_progress
function.purpose: This function returns true when testing is in progress (setup is finished).

function.name: shutdown
function.purpose: This function shuts down the framework and clears up its mono-state.

description.para: It needs to be at the very end of test module execution

function.name: current_auto_test_suite

description.para: test suite to push back to the queue
should we push ts to the queue or pop leaf test suite instead

function.purpose: Provides both read and write access to current "leaf" auto test suite during the test unit registration phase.

description.para:
During auto-registration phase the framework maintain a FIFO queue of test units being registered. New test units become children of the current "leaf" test suite and if this is test suite it is pushed back into queue and becomes a new leaf. When test suite registration is completed, a test suite is popped from the back of the queue. Only automatically registered test suites should be added to this queue. Master test suite is always a zero element in this queue, so if no other test suites are registered all test cases are added to master test suite. This function facilitates all three possible actions:
if no argument are provided it returns the current queue leaf test suite
if test suite is provided and no second argument are set, test suite is added to the queue
if no test suite are provided and last argument is false, the semantic of this function is similar to queue pop: last element is popped from the queue

function.name: register_test_unit

description.para: test case to register

function.purpose: This function add new test case into the global collection of test units the framework aware of.

description.para: This function also assignes unique test unit id for every test case. Later on one can use this id to locate the test case if necessary. This is the way for the framework to maintain weak references between test units.

function.name: register_test_unit

description.para: test suite to register

function.purpose: This function add new test suite into the global collection of test units the framework aware of.

description.para: This function also assignes unique test unit id for every test suite. Later on one can use this id to locate the test case if necessary. This is the way for the framework to maintain weak references between test units.

function.name: deregister_test_unit

description.para: test unit to deregister

function.purpose: This function removes the test unit from the collection of known test units and destroys the test unit object.

description.para: This function also assigns unique test unit id for every test case. Later on one can use this id to located the test case if necessary. This is the way for the framework to maintain weak references between test units.

function.name: clear
function.purpose: After this call the framework can be reinitialized to perform a second test run during the same program lifetime.

function.name: register_observer

description.para: test observer object to add

function.purpose: Observer lifetime should exceed the the testing execution timeframe.

function.name: deregister_observer

description.para: test observer object to exclude

function.purpose: Excldes the observer object form the framework's list of test observers.

function.name: add_context

description.para: context frame message
is this sticky frame or not

function.purpose: Records context frame message.

description.para: Some context frames are sticky - they can only explicitly cleared by specifying context id. Other (non sticky) context frames cleared after every assertion.

returns.para: id of the newly created frame

function.name: clear_context
function.purpose: Erases context frame (when test exits context scope)

description.para: If context_id is passed clears that specific context frame identified by this id, otherwise clears all non sticky contexts.

function.name: get_context
function.purpose: Produces an instance of small "delegate" object, which facilitates access to collected context.

function.name: master_test_suite
function.purpose: There is only only master test suite per test module.

returns.para: a reference the master test suite instance

function.name: current_test_case
function.purpose: This function provides an access to the test case currently being executed.

description.para:
This function is only valid during test execution phase.
See Also:
current_test_case_id

function.name: current_test_case_id
function.purpose: This function provides an access to an id of the test case currently being executed.

description.para:
This function safer than current_test_case, cause if wont throw if no test case is being executed.
See Also:
current_test_case

function.name: get

description.para: id of a test unit to locate
type of a test unit to locate

function.purpose: This function provides access to a test unit by id and type combination. It will throw if no test unit located.

function.name: get

purpose.para: compile time type of test unit to get (test_suite or test_case)

description.para: id of test unit to get

function.purpose: This function template provides access to a typed test unit by id.

description.para: It will throw if you specify incorrect test unit type

function.name: run

description.para: Optional id of the test unit or test unit itself from which the test is started. If absent, master test suite is used
true == continue test if it was already started, false == restart the test from scratch regardless

function.purpose: Initiates test execution.

description.para: This function is used to start the test execution from a specific "root" test unit. If no root provided, test is started from master test suite. This second argument facilitates an ability of the test cases to start some other test units (primarily used internally for self testing).

function.name: run
function.purpose: Initiates test execution. Same as other overload.

function.name: exception_caught
function.purpose: Reports uncaught exception to all test observers.

function.name: test_unit_aborted
function.purpose: Reports aborted test unit to all test observers.

description.para: Different depending on whether BOOST_TEST_ALTERNATIVE_INIT_API is defined or not

method.name: log_start

description.para: output stream to write a messages to
total test case amount to be run

method.purpose: Invoked at the beginning of test module execution.

method.name: log_finish

description.para: output stream to write a messages into

method.purpose: Invoked at the end of test module execution.

method.name: log_build_info

description.para: output stream to write a messages into

method.purpose: Invoked when Unit Test Framework build information is requested.

method.name: test_unit_start

description.para: output stream to write a messages into
test unit being started

method.purpose: Invoked when test unit starts (either test suite or test case)

method.name: test_unit_finish

description.para: output stream to write a messages into
test unit being finished
time in milliseconds spend executing this test unit

method.purpose: Invoked when test unit finishes.

method.name: test_unit_skipped

description.para: output stream to write a messages into
skipped test unit
explanation why was it skipped

method.purpose: Invoked if test unit skipped for any reason.

method.name: log_exception_start

description.para: output stream to write a messages into
information about the last checkpoint before the exception was triggered
information about the caught exception

method.purpose: Invoked when Unit Test Framework detects uncaught exception.

description.para:
Call to this function starts uncaught exception report. It is going to followed by context information. Report is finalized by call to log_exception_finish.
See Also:
log_exception_finish

method.name: log_exception_finish

description.para: output stream to write a messages into

method.purpose: Invoked when Unit Test Framework detects uncaught exception.

description.para:
Call to this function finishes uncaught exception report.
See Also:
log_exception_start

method.name: log_entry_start

description.para: output stream to write a messages into
log entry attributes
log entry type log_entry_finish

method.purpose: Invoked by Unit Test Framework to start new log entry.

description.para:
Call to this function starts new log entry. It is followed by series of log_entry_value calls and finally call to log_entry_finish. A log entry may consist of one or more values being reported. Some of these values will be plain strings, while others can be complicated expressions in a form of "lazy" expression template lazy_ostream.
See Also:
log_entry_value, log_entry_finish

method.name: log_entry_value

description.para: output stream to write a messages into.
log entry string value

method.purpose: Invoked by Unit Test Framework to report a log entry content.

description.para:
This is one of two overloaded methods to report log entry content. This one is used to report plain string value.
See Also:
log_entry_start, log_entry_finish

method.name: log_entry_value

description.para: output stream to write a messages into
log entry "lazy" value

method.purpose: Invoked by Unit Test Framework to report a log entry content.

description.para:
This is one of two overloaded methods to report log entry content. This one is used to report some complicated expression passed as an expression template lazy_ostream. In most cases default implementation provided by the framework should work as is (it just converts the lazy expression into a string.
See Also:
log_entry_start, log_entry_finish

method.name: log_entry_finish

description.para: output stream to write a messages into

method.purpose: Invoked by Unit Test Framework to finish a log entry report.

method.name: entry_context_start

description.para: output stream to write a messages into
entry log_leveg, to be used to fine tune the message

method.purpose: Invoked by Unit Test Framework to start log entry context report.

description.para:
Unit Test Framework logs for failed assertions and uncaught exceptions context if one was defined by a test module. Context consists of multiple "scopes" identified by description messages assigned by the test module using BOOST_TEST_INFO/BOOST_TEST_CONTEXT statements.
See Also:
log_entry_context, entry_context_finish

method.name: log_entry_context

description.para: output stream to write a messages into
context "scope" description

method.purpose: Invoked by Unit Test Framework to report log entry context "scope" description.

description.para:
Each "scope" description is reported by separate call to log_entry_context.
See Also:
log_entry_start, entry_context_finish

method.name: entry_context_finish

description.para: output stream to write a messages into

method.purpose: Invoked by Unit Test Framework to finish log entry context report.

method.name: test_unit_skipped
method.purpose: Deprecated version of this interface.

method.name: log_start

description.para: output stream to write a messages to
total test case amount to be run

method.purpose: Invoked at the beginning of test module execution.

method.name: log_finish

description.para: output stream to write a messages into

method.purpose: Invoked at the end of test module execution.

method.name: log_build_info

description.para: output stream to write a messages into

method.purpose: Invoked when Unit Test Framework build information is requested.

method.name: test_unit_start

description.para: output stream to write a messages into
test unit being started

method.purpose: Invoked when test unit starts (either test suite or test case)

method.name: test_unit_finish

description.para: output stream to write a messages into
test unit being finished
time in milliseconds spend executing this test unit

method.purpose: Invoked when test unit finishes.

method.name: test_unit_skipped

description.para: output stream to write a messages into
skipped test unit
explanation why was it skipped

method.purpose: Invoked if test unit skipped for any reason.

method.name: log_exception_start

description.para: output stream to write a messages into
information about the last checkpoint before the exception was triggered
information about the caught exception

method.purpose: Invoked when Unit Test Framework detects uncaught exception.

description.para:
Call to this function starts uncaught exception report. It is going to followed by context information. Report is finalized by call to log_exception_finish.
See Also:
log_exception_finish

method.name: log_exception_finish

description.para: output stream to write a messages into

method.purpose: Invoked when Unit Test Framework detects uncaught exception.

description.para:
Call to this function finishes uncaught exception report.
See Also:
log_exception_start

method.name: log_entry_start

description.para: output stream to write a messages into
log entry attributes
log entry type log_entry_finish

method.purpose: Invoked by Unit Test Framework to start new log entry.

description.para:
Call to this function starts new log entry. It is followed by series of log_entry_value calls and finally call to log_entry_finish. A log entry may consist of one or more values being reported. Some of these values will be plain strings, while others can be complicated expressions in a form of "lazy" expression template lazy_ostream.
See Also:
log_entry_value, log_entry_finish

method.name: log_entry_value

description.para: output stream to write a messages into.
log entry string value

method.purpose: Invoked by Unit Test Framework to report a log entry content.

description.para:
This is one of two overloaded methods to report log entry content. This one is used to report plain string value.
See Also:
log_entry_start, log_entry_finish

method.name: log_entry_finish

description.para: output stream to write a messages into

method.purpose: Invoked by Unit Test Framework to finish a log entry report.

method.name: entry_context_start

description.para: output stream to write a messages into
entry log_leveg, to be used to fine tune the message

method.purpose: Invoked by Unit Test Framework to start log entry context report.

description.para:
Unit Test Framework logs for failed assertions and uncaught exceptions context if one was defined by a test module. Context consists of multiple "scopes" identified by description messages assigned by the test module using BOOST_TEST_INFO/BOOST_TEST_CONTEXT statements.
See Also:
log_entry_context, entry_context_finish

method.name: log_entry_context

description.para: output stream to write a messages into
context "scope" description

method.purpose: Invoked by Unit Test Framework to report log entry context "scope" description.

description.para:
Each "scope" description is reported by separate call to log_entry_context.
See Also:
log_entry_start, entry_context_finish

method.name: entry_context_finish

description.para: output stream to write a messages into

method.purpose: Invoked by Unit Test Framework to finish log entry context report.

method.name: test_unit_skipped
method.purpose: Deprecated version of this interface.

method.name: log_entry_value

description.para: output stream to write a messages into
log entry "lazy" value

method.purpose: Invoked by Unit Test Framework to report a log entry content.

description.para:
This is one of two overloaded methods to report log entry content. This one is used to report some complicated expression passed as an expression template lazy_ostream. In most cases default implementation provided by the framework should work as is (it just converts the lazy expression into a string.
See Also:
log_entry_start, log_entry_finish

header.name: boost/test/parameterized_test.hpp
header.para: generators and helper macros for parameterized tests

header.name: boost/test/progress_monitor.hpp
header.para: defines simple text based progress monitor

class.name: progress_monitor_t
class.purpose: This class implements test observer interface and updates test progress as test units finish or get aborted.

header.name: boost/test/results_collector.hpp
header.para: defines testing result collector components
Defines class results_collector_t that is responsible for gathering test results and class test_results for presenting this information to end-user

class.name: test_results
class.purpose: Collection of attributes constituting test unit results.

description.para: This class is a collection of attributes describing testing results. The atributes presented as public properties on an instance of the class. In addition summary conclusion methods are presented to generate simple answer to pass/fail question

method.name: BOOST_READONLY_PROPERTY
method.purpose: Type representing counter like public property.

method.name: BOOST_READONLY_PROPERTY
method.purpose: Type representing boolean like public property.

class.name: results_collector_t
class.purpose: This class implements test observer interface to collect the result of test unit execution.

method.name: results

description.para: id of a test unit

method.purpose: Results access per test unit.

header.name: boost/test/results_reporter.hpp
header.para: defines testing result reporter interfaces
This file defines interfaces that are responsible for results reporting. Interface is presented in a form of free standing function implemented in namespace result_reporter

class.name: format
class.purpose: Results report formatter interface.

description.para: This is abstract interface for the report formatter used by results reporter routines. You can define a custom formatter by implementing this interface and setting the formatter using set_format function. This is usually done during test module initialization

function.name: set_level

description.para: report level

function.purpose: Sets reporting level.

description.para:
There are only four possible levels for results report:
confirmation report (boost::unit_test::CONFIRMATION_REPORT). This report level only produces short confirmation message about test module pass/fail status
short report (boost::unit_test::SHORT_REPORT). This report level produces short summary report for failed/passed assertions and test units.
detailed report (boost::unit_test::DETAILED_REPORT). This report level produces detailed report per test unit for passed/failed assertions and uncaught exceptions
no report (boost::unit_test::NO_REPORT). This report level produces no results report. This is used for test modules running as part of some kind of continues integration framework

function.name: set_stream
function.purpose: Sets output stream for results reporting.

description.para: By default std::cerr is used. Use this function to set a different stream. The framework refers to the stream by reference, so you need to make sure the stream object lifetime exceeds the testing main scope.

function.name: set_format

description.para: one of the presefined enumeration values for output formats

function.purpose: Sets one of the predefined formats.

description.para:
The framework implements two results report formats:
plain human readable format (boost::unit_test::OF_CLF)
XML format (boost::unit_test::OF_XML)

function.name: set_format

description.para: pointer to heap allocated instance of custom report formatter class

function.purpose: Sets custom report formatter.

description.para: The framework takes ownership of the pointer passed as an argument. So this should be a pointer to a heap allocated object

function.name: get_stream
function.purpose: Access to configured results reporter stream.

description.para: Use this stream to report additional information abut test module execution

header.name: boost/test/tools/assertion_result.hpp
header.para: Enhanced result for test predicate that include message explaining failure.

class.name: assertion_result
class.purpose: Type used for storing the result of an assertion.

header.name: boost/test/tools/detail/bitwise_manip.hpp
header.para: Bitwise comparison manipulator implementation.

header.name: boost/test/tools/detail/lexicographic_manip.hpp
header.para: Lexicographic comparison manipulator implementation.

header.name: boost/test/tools/detail/per_element_manip.hpp
header.para: Per element comparison manipulator implementation.

struct.name: per_element
struct.purpose: Per element comparison manipulator, for containers.

header.name: boost/test/tools/detail/tolerance_manip.hpp
header.para: Floating point comparison tolerance manipulators.
This file defines several manipulators for floating point comparison. These manipulators are intended to be used with BOOST_TEST.

description.para: Tolerance manipulator
These functions return a manipulator that can be used in conjunction with BOOST_TEST in order to specify the tolerance with which floating point comparisons are made.

header.name: boost/test/tools/floating_point_comparison.hpp
header.para: algorithms for comparing floating point values

struct.name: tolerance_based
struct.purpose: Indicates if a type can be compared using a tolerance scheme.

description.para: This is a metafunction that should evaluate to mpl::true_ if the type T can be compared using a tolerance based method, typically for floating point types.
This metafunction can be specialized further to declare user types that are floating point (eg. boost.multiprecision).

class.name: close_at_tolerance
class.purpose: Predicate for comparing floating point numbers.

description.para: This predicate is used to compare floating point numbers. In addition the comparison produces maximum related differnce, which can be used to generate detailed error message The methods for comparing floating points are detailed in the documentation. The method is chosen by the boost::math::fpc::strength given at construction.

method.name: fraction_tolerance
method.purpose: Returns the tolerance.

method.name: strength
method.purpose: Returns the comparison method.

method.name: tested_rel_diff
method.purpose: Returns the failing fraction.

description.para: first floating point number to be compared
second floating point number to be compared
Compares two floating point numbers a and b such that their "left" relative difference |a-b|/a and/or "right" relative difference |a-b|/b does not exceed specified relative (fraction) tolerance.

What is reported by tested_rel_diff in case of failure depends on the comparison method:
for FPC_STRONG: the max of the two fractions
for FPC_WEAK: the min of the two fractions The rationale behind is to report the tolerance to set in order to make a test pass.

class.name: small_with_tolerance
class.purpose: Predicate for comparing floating point numbers against 0.

description.para: Serves the same purpose as boost::math::fpc::close_at_tolerance, but used when one of the operand is null.

enum.name: strength

enumvalue.name: FPC_STRONG
enumvalue.purpose: "Very close" - equation 2' in docs, the default

enum.purpose: Method for comparing floating point numbers.

header.name: boost/test/tools/output_test_stream.hpp
header.para: output_test_stream class definition

class.name: output_test_stream
class.purpose: Class to be used to simplify testing of ostream-based output operations.

method.name: is_empty

description.para: if true, flushes the stream after the call

method.purpose: Checks if the stream is empty.

method.name: check_length

description.para: target length
if true, flushes the stream after the call. Set to false to call additional checks on the same content.

method.purpose: Checks the length of the stream.

method.name: is_equal

description.para: the target stream
if true, flushes the stream after the call.

method.purpose: Checks the content of the stream against a string.

method.name: match_pattern

description.para: if true, flushes the stream after the call.

method.purpose: Checks the content of the stream against a pattern file.

method.name: flush
method.purpose: Flushes the stream.

description.para: indicates the name of the file for matching. If the string is empty, the standard input or output streams are used instead (depending on match_or_save)
if true, the pattern file will be read, otherwise it will be written
if false, opens the stream in binary mode. Otherwise the stream is opened with default flags and the carriage returns are ignored.

header.name: boost/test/unit_test.hpp
header.para: Entry point into the Unit Test Framework.
This header should be the only header necessary to include to start using the framework

header.name: boost/test/unit_test_log_formatter.hpp
header.para: Defines unit test log formatter interface.
You can define a class with implements this interface and use an instance of it as a Unit Test Framework log formatter

data-member.name: m_file_name
data-member.purpose: log entry file name

data-member.name: m_line_num
data-member.purpose: log entry line number

data-member.name: m_level
data-member.purpose: log entry level

data-member.name: m_file_name
data-member.purpose: log checkpoint file name

data-member.name: m_line_num
data-member.purpose: log checkpoint file name

data-member.name: m_message
data-member.purpose: log checkpoint message

class.name: unit_test_log_formatter
class.purpose: Abstract Unit Test Framework log formatter interface.

description.para: During the test module execution Unit Test Framework can report messages about success or failure of assertions, which test suites are being run and more (specifically which messages are reported depends on log level threshold selected by the user). All these messages constitute Unit Test Framework log. There are many ways (formats) to present these messages to the user. Boost.Test comes with two formats: "Compiler-like log format" and "XML based log format". Former is intended for human consumption and later is intended for processing by automated regression test systems. If you want to produce some other format you need to implement class with specific interface and use method unit_test_log_t::set_formatter during a test module initialization to set an active formatter. The class unit_test_log_formatter defines this interface.

This interface requires you to format all possible messages being produced in the log. These includes error messages about failed assertions, messages about caught exceptions and information messages about test units being started/ended. All the methods in this interface takes a reference to standard stream as a first argument. This is where final messages needs to be directed to. Also you are given all the information necessary to produce a message.

enum.name: log_entry_types
enum.purpose: Types of log entries (messages written into a log)

method.name: log_start

description.para: output stream to write a messages to
total test case amount to be run

method.purpose: Invoked at the beginning of test module execution.

method.name: log_finish

description.para: output stream to write a messages into

method.purpose: Invoked at the end of test module execution.

method.name: log_build_info

description.para: output stream to write a messages into

method.purpose: Invoked when Unit Test Framework build information is requested.

method.name: test_unit_start

description.para: output stream to write a messages into
test unit being started

method.purpose: Invoked when test unit starts (either test suite or test case)

method.name: test_unit_finish

description.para: output stream to write a messages into
test unit being finished
time in milliseconds spend executing this test unit

method.purpose: Invoked when test unit finishes.

description.para: output stream to write a messages into
skipped test unit
explanation why was it skipped

method.purpose: Invoked if test unit skipped for any reason.

header.name: boost/test/utils/algorithm.hpp
header.para: Addition to STL algorithms.

function.name: mismatch

description.para: - first collection begin iterator
- first collection end iterator
- second collection begin iterator
- second collection end iterator

function.purpose: this algorithm search through two collections for first mismatch position that get returned as a pair of iterators, first pointing to the mismatch position in first collection, second iterator in second one

function.name: mismatch

description.para: - first collection begin iterator
- first collection end iterator
- second collection begin iterator
- second collection end iterator
- predicate to be used for search

function.purpose: this algorithm search through two collections for first mismatch position that get returned as a pair of iterators, first pointing to the mismatch position in first collection, second iterator in second one. This algorithms uses supplied predicate for collection elements comparison

function.name: find_first_not_of

description.para: - first collection begin iterator
- first collection end iterator
- second collection begin iterator
- second collection end iterator

function.purpose: this algorithm search through first collection for first element that does not belong a second one

function.name: find_first_not_of

description.para: - first collection begin iterator
- first collection end iterator
- second collection begin iterator
- second collection end iterator
- predicate to be used for search

function.purpose: this algorithm search through first collection for first element that does not satisfy binary predicate in conjunction will any element in second collection

function.name: find_last_of

description.para: - first collection begin iterator
- first collection end iterator
- second collection begin iterator
- second collection end iterator

function.purpose: this algorithm search through first collection for last element that belongs to a second one

function.name: find_last_of

description.para: - first collection begin iterator
- first collection end iterator
- second collection begin iterator
- second collection end iterator
- predicate to be used for search

function.purpose: this algorithm search through first collection for last element that satisfy binary predicate in conjunction will at least one element in second collection

function.name: find_last_not_of

description.para: - first collection begin iterator
- first collection end iterator
- second collection begin iterator
- second collection end iterator

function.purpose: this algorithm search through first collection for last element that does not belong to a second one

function.name: find_last_not_of

description.para: - first collection begin iterator
- first collection end iterator
- second collection begin iterator
- second collection end iterator
- predicate to be used for search

function.purpose: this algorithm search through first collection for last element that does not satisfy binary predicate in conjunction will any element in second collection

struct.purpose: is_named_param_pack<T>::value is true if T is parameters pack

struct.name: param_type
struct.purpose: param_type<Params,Keyword,Default>::type is is the type of the parameter corresponding to the Keyword (if parameter is present) or Default

struct.name: has_param
struct.purpose: has_param<Params,Keyword>::value is true id Params has parameter corresponding to the Keyword

method.name: operator,
method.type: named_parameter_combine< NP, named_parameter< T, unique_id, RefType > >

copy-assignment.type: named_parameter< char const *, unique_id, char const * >

function.name: opt_append
function.type: enable_if_c<!has_param< Params, keyword< typename NP::id > >::value, named_parameter_combine< NP, Params > >::type
